description: From Latin perōrō (“I speak at length, I conclude a speech”) (from per- (“very”) + ōrō (“I speak, I orate”) (English orate)) + -ation (“action (nominalizer)”) (from Latin -ātiō).

entries.meaning: The concluding section of a discourse, either written or oral, in which the orator or writer sums up and commends his topic to his audience, particularly as used in the technical sense of a component of ancient Roman oratorical delivery.
examples: This passage is virtually the peroration of the Ethics; the few paragraphs that follow are concerned with the transition to politics.

entries.meaning: A discourse or rhetorical argument in general.
